head.title: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Cubans

hedline.hl1: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Cubans

abstract.p: Tanya Hernandez letter, responding to June 5 article Best of Friends, Worlds Apart, in series How Race Is Lived in America, contends racism is entrenched even in intimate friendships in Latin America because issue is not openly discussed or acknowledged

block.p: Re ''Best of Friends, Worlds Apart'' (front page, June 5):

For black Cubans like Joel Ruiz, the difference in treatment they receive at the hands of racially biased Cubans in the United States as opposed to Cuba is not so much a qualitative difference as a difference in cultural expectations of what is appropriate. Because Latin American racism is not openly discussed or acknowledged, it is entrenched even in intimate friendships.
Re ''Best of Friends, Worlds Apart'' (front page, June 5):

For black Cubans like Joel Ruiz, the difference in treatment they receive at the hands of racially biased Cubans in the United States as opposed to Cuba is not so much a qualitative difference as a difference in cultural expectations of what is appropriate. Because Latin American racism is not openly discussed or acknowledged, it is entrenched even in intimate friendships.
The United States did not teach Achmed Valdes to verbally disparage people of African ancestry. Such biased notions have long existed in Cuba and elsewhere in Latin America.
The writer is an associate professor of law at St. John's University.
